Award.AwardTitle: Scalable Assembly of Flexible and Thermally Conductive Graphene Paper Macroscopic Structures for Effective Thermal Management in Electronic Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Innovative thermal management solutions to address ever-increasing challenges of heat generation are critical for future higher power, more compact and ultra-lightweight electronics. Current state-of-the-art materials such as flexible graphitic films for thermal management of high power electronics are not cost-effective since they are expensive to manufacture. Graphene, a single layer of carbon atoms bonded in a hexagonal lattice, is one of the thinnest and strongest of materials, and also displays intrinsically exceptional thermal conductivity. Macroscopic graphene structures, assembled from single layer graphene nanosheets, offer immense potential as advanced materials for effective thermal management. However, key challenges exist for the scalable assembly of two-dimensional graphene nanosheets into three-dimensional macroscopic structures, which is usually accompanied by a significant reduction of the thermal properties. To find solutions to address these key challenges, this award supports fundamental nano-scale manufacturing science of effectively assembling graphene nanosheets into large-scale three-dimensional architectures that are designed for performance in a cost-effective manner. These assembled macroscopic structures are highly flexible, mechanically robust and exceptionally thermal conductive, unlocking the enormous commercial potential of graphene as advanced materials for nano-scale thermal management. The results from this project will benefit the US economy and society. This project has synergistic educational and outreach impacts through integration of research and education and engaging participation of underrepresented groups.

This project will develop innovative approaches of integrating two well-established industrial processes of electrospray deposition and roll-to-roll processing for manufacturing flexible graphene papers with breakthrough thermal properties. The research will establish process-microstructure-property relationships in electrospray deposited and assembled graphene papers through experimentation. Post-assembly high temperature annealing and mechanical compaction for microstructural optimization and graphene sheet alignment will be performed in order to improve properties. A game-changer is the direct manufacturing of the graphene nanosheets from defect-free graphene using electrospray deposition. Superior properties will be achieved in the macroscopic graphene structure without the penalty of traditional energy-intensive high temperature annealing. The scalable and cost-effective approach developed in assembling two-dimensional nanosheets into three-dimensional functional architectures will have a broader impact on controllable assembly and design of functional architectures of other two-dimensional single atomic layer materials beyond graphene.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nontechnical

 Macroscopic graphene structures, assembled from single layer graphene nanosheets, show great promise in numerous important technological applications ranging from structural composites, electrodes for batteries, super-capacitors and fuel cells, optically transparent films for solar cells, stretchable/foldable electronics, bio-chemical sensors, corrosion resistant coatings, heat spreaders for thermal management, photo-catalysts to membranes for gas separator, next generation nano-filtration and desalination technologies. However, superior properties of single layer graphene typically cannot be achieved upon assembly of individual graphene nanosheets into macroscopic structures due to non-optimized microstructure, graphene alignment and existence of defects. This project targeted an innovative approach of integrating  two well-established industrial processes of electrospray deposition (ESD) and roll-to-roll production for scale-up manufacturing of flexible graphene papers and achieve breakthrough in thermal-electrical properties.

 

Intellectual Merit: The key advancements achieved include: (1) exploration of the correlation of the ESD process – microstructure control – properties of the assembled graphene papers, enabling large-scale manufacturing of macroscopic graphene structures; and the post-assembly high temperature annealing and mechanical compaction in controlling defects and graphene sheet alignment in order to improve properties; (2) a cost-effective process of directly manufacturing highly thermally-conductive graphene papers by ESD from defect-free graphene; and (3) technology demonstration of commercialization potential of the macroscopic graphene papers as advanced heat spreader materials and highly conductive composites for effective thermal management. Though extensively used for scale-up manufacturing and assembly of nanostructures, ESD and roll-to-roll processes for assembling macroscopic graphene papers from 2D graphene sheet is still in cradle and represent a viable and promising solution for scalable assembly of graphene into 3D macroscopic structures. The direct ESD deposition of graphene paper from defect-free graphene attain superior properties of high quality graphene without penalty from energy-intensive high temperature annealing process. 

 

Broader Impact: The highly thermally-conductive graphene papers hold immerse potential as advanced heat spreading materials in addressing today’s challenging thermal management issues encountered with higher power, smarter, smaller and more compact electronics. The assembled macroscopic structures are highly flexible, mechanically robust, and exceptionally electrical conductive, and provide enormous opportunities and advantages for a wide range of important technological applications. The scalable and cost-effective approach developed in re-assembling 2D nanosheets into 3D functional architectures will have a broader impact on controllable assembly and design of functional architectures of other 2D sheet materials beyond graphene. This research program trained graduate and undergraduate students working in key fields of macroscopic graphene fiber/paper and their composite fabrication, manufacturing and characterization. This project produced seven publications in peer-reviewed journals including two articles in high profile journals (Science and Nature Nanotechnology), one conference paper and seven invited/contributed presentations in international/national conferences.

Publications Produced as a Result of this Research

  1. Guoqing Xin, Weiguang Zhu, Yanxiang Deng, Jie Cheng, Lucy Zhang, Aram Chung, Suvranu De, and Jie Lian, Microfluidics-enabled Orientation and Microstructure Control of Macroscopic Graphene Fibers, Nature Nanotechnology (2019) s41565-018-0330-9.
  2. S Wang, S Han, G Xin, J Lin, R Wei, J Lian, K Sun, X Zu, Q. K. Yu, High-quality graphene directly grown on Cu nanoparticles for Cu-graphene nanocomposites, Materials & Design, 139 (2018) 181-187.
  3. Guoqing Xin, Weiguang Zhu, Tiankai Yao, Spencer M. Scott, Jie Lian, Microstructure control of macroscopic graphene paper by electrospray deposition and its effect on thermal and electrical conductivities, Applied Physics Letters 110 (2017) 091909.
  4. Guoqing Xin, Jie Lian, Scalable assembly of graphene nanosheets into 3D macroscopic structures for effective thermal management, 2016 IEEE Nanotechnology Materials and Devices Conference (NMDC), page 1-2.
  5. Guoqing Xin, Tiankai Yao, Hongtao Sun, Spencer Michael Scott, Dali Shao, Gongkai Wang, and Jie Lian, Highly Thermally Conductive and Mechanically Strong Graphene Fibers, Science 349 (2015) 1083.
  6. Junshuang Zhou, Jie Lian, Li Hou, Junchuan Zhang, Huiyang Gou, Meirong Xia, Yufeng Zhao, Timothy A. Strobel, Lu Tao, Faming Gao, Ultrahigh Volumetric Capacitance and Cyclic Stability of Fluorine and Nitrogen co-doped Carbon Microspheres, Nature Communications 6 (2015) 8503.
  7. Dali Shao, Jian Gao, Philippe Chow, Hongtao Sun, Guoqing Xin, Prachi Sharma, Jie Lian, Shayla Sawyer and Nikhil A. Koratkar, Organic-Inorganic Hetero-Interfaces for Ultra-Sensitive Detection of UV light, Nano Letters 15 (2015) 3787-3792.
  8. Dali Shao, Jian Gao, Guoqing Xin, Yiping Wang, Lu Li, Jie Lian, Shayla Sawyer and Nikhil A. Koratkar, Cl-doped ZnO Nanowire Arrays on 3D Graphene Foam with Highly Efficient Field Emission, and Photocatalytic Properties, Small 11 (2015) 4785-4792.

Modified by: Jie Lian
